prefix: Approach the following question the way someone with a PhD in mathematics would.
problem_prompt: Approach the following question the way someone with a PhD in mathematics would. How many triangles can be formed using the vertices of a regular dodecagon (a 12-sided polygon)?
solution: No three vertices are collinear, so any combination of 3 vertices will make a triangle. Choosing 3 out of 12 is $\binom{12}{3}=\boxed{220}.$
gpt_response:
To calculate the number of triangles that can be formed using the vertices of a regular dodecagon, we must first consider the total number of ways in which we can choose 3 vertices out of the 12 vertices of the dodecagon. This can be calculated using the combination formula:

C(12, 3) = 12! / (3!(12-3)!) = 220

Therefore, there are a total of 220 possible combinations of 3 vertices that can form triangles using the vertices of a regular dodecagon.
